page.title: 09HOUSING IN CRUWYS MORCHARD
page.content: Houses fall into two types, older stone and cob farmhouses and cottages, and recent houses and bungalows. Many old farmhouses have a basic medieval plan of cross-passage and two or three rooms which were originally open to the roof. Chimneys, a first floor and ceilings were gradually added. Cottages, initially one-up one-down, have been enlarged or combined to provide better accommodation. Originally thatched, most houses now have slate roofs. The newer houses include council and privately built homes. All the council houses are semi-detached, tenants are buying some. Bungalows are privately built, nearly all in Pennymoor in the last 25 years. The Manor House is mainly Georgian but has a medieval core including an oak panelled ceiling in the older part.
